name: Hexan-2-one
Reason: Starting with the basic unit, hexane, which has a melting point of -95.3 degrees Celsius. The carbonyl group (C=O) in hexan-2-one generally increases the melting point due to the possibility of stronger dipole-dipole interactions and potential hydrogen bonding interactions with other molecules, or the electron-donating effect of nearby alkyl groups which can stabilize the carbonyl group. Considering the carbonyl group may increase the melting point by about +20 to +40 degrees Celsius. However, since this is a ketone and it has two alkyl groups on either side of the carbonyl, it can destabilize the molecule slightly making it more susceptible to melting. Therefore, the increase due to the carbonyl might be towards the lower end of the estimate. We'll consider an increase of +20 degrees Celsius. Also, Ketone compound has high symmetry compared to alcohol or carboxylic acid, thus it has moderate ability of intermolecular interaction.

name: Hexan-2-one
Reason: Starting with the basic unit, hexane, which has a melting point of -95.3 degrees Celsius. The carbonyl group (C=O) in hexan-2-one increases the melting point because it introduces stronger dipole-dipole interactions than the C-C and C-H interactions in alkanes, due to the polar nature of the C=O bond. However, hexan-2-one does not have the ability to form hydrogen bonds like alcohols or carboxylic acids, which limits the increase in melting point. Given that the carbonyl group typically increases the melting point by about +20 to +40 degrees Celsius in comparison to similar nonpolar compounds, we should consider a moderate increase. Assuming the influence of the carbonyl group increases the melting point by an intermediate value of +30 degrees Celsius from the base value of hexane, we will predict the melting point accordingly.
